entry.title: Spring [5] - Web MVC Development
entry.content:
Spring [5] - Web MVC Development

Member Web Function - Add Home Controller

Add Home Controller

package hello.hellospring.controller;

import org.springframework.stereotype.Controller;
import org.springframework.web.bind.annotation.GetMapping;

@Controller
public class HomeController {

    @GetMapping("/")
    public String home() {
        return "home";
    }
}

Member Control Home

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html xmlns:th="http://www.thymeleaf.org">
<body>

<div class="container">
    <div>
        <h1>Hello Spring</h1>
        <p>회원 기능</p>
        <p>
            <a href="/members/new">회원 가입</a>
            <a href="/members">회원 목록</a>
        </p>
    </div>
</div> <!-- container -->

</body>
</html>

Reference

  • https://www.inflearn.com/roadmaps/373

entry.title: Spring [4] - Spring Bin and Dependencies Relation

link.title: Spring [4] - Spring Bin and Dependencies Relation

entry.content:
Spring [4] - Spring Bin and Dependencies Relation

Register Srping Bin and Set Dependencies Relation

  • Set dependcies relation for member controller to use member service and member repository

Add dependencies relations in member controller

package hello.hellospring.controller;

import hello.hellospring.service.MemberService;
import org.springframework.beans.factory.annotation.Autowired;
import org.springframework.stereotype.Controller;

@Controller
public class MemberController {

    private final MemberService memberService;

    @Autowired
    public MemberController(MemberService memberService) {
        this.memberService = memberService;
    }
}
  • If constructor has @Autowird, Spring container finds the related object. This method of dependencies relation outside is called DI(Dependency Injection)
  • Prior to this test, the developer had to put it in manually, but spring does it for us due to @Autowired

Error occur

Consider defining a bean of type 'hello.hellospring.services.MemberService' in your configuration.
  • There are 2 ways to register Spring bin
    • Component scan and dependencies relation auto set
    • Register Spring bin using Java code

Component Scan and Dependencies Relation Auto Set

  • @Component: Spring bin is automatically registered if annotation exists
  • @Controller: Controller got automatically registered to Spring bin due to component scan
  • The following annotation including @Component get automatically registered to Spring bin:
    • @Controller
    • @Service
    • @Repository

Member Service Spring Bin Register

@Service
public class MemberService {

    private final MemberRepository memberRepository;

    @Autowired
    public MemberService(MemberRepository memberRepository) {
        this.memberRepository = memberRepository;
    }

}

Tip

  • If constructor uses @Autowired, Srping bin will be found to be injected at the time the object is created

Member Repository Spring Bin Register

@Repository
public class MemoryMemberRepository implements MemberRepository {}
  • memberService and memberRepository are registered to Spring bin

Tip

  • Spring registers in single tone by default when registering Spring Continaer and Spring Bin.

Register Spring Bin Using Java Code

  • Remove @Serivce, @Repository annotation and continue
package hello.hellospring;

import hello.hellospring.repository.MemberRepository;
import hello.hellospring.repository.MemoryMemberRepository;
import hello.hellospring.service.MemberService;
import org.springframework.context.annotation.Bean;
import org.springframework.context.annotation.Configuration;

@Configuration
public class SpringConfig {

    @Bean
    public MemberService memberService() {
        return new MemberService(memberRepository());
    }

    @Bean
    public MemberRepository memberRepository() {
        return new MemoryMemberRepository();
    }
}

Reference

  • https://www.inflearn.com/roadmaps/373
entry.summary: Spring [4] - Spring Bin and Dependencies Relation

entry.title: Spring[3] - Backend Development
entry.content:
Spring[3] - Backend Development

Business Requirements

  • Data: member id, name
  • Function: member registration, member lookup
  • Data Storage is not selected yet(a virtual scenario)

Typical Web Application Hierarchy

  • Controller: web MVC’s controller role
  • Service: essential business logic implementation
  • Repository: database access, save and manage domain object in DB
  • Domain: business domain object, such as member, order, coupon etc. are saved and managed in database

Create member domain and repository

member object

public class Member {

    private Long id;
    private String name;

    public Long getId() {
        return id;
    }

    public void setId(Long id) {
        this.id = id;
    }

    public String getName() {
        return name;
    }

    public void setName(String name) {
        this.name = name;
    }
}

member repository interface

package hello.hellospring.repository;

import hello.hellospring.domain.Member;

import java.util.List;
import java.util.Optional;

public interface MemberRepository {
    Member save(Member member);
    Optional<Member> findById(Long id);
    Optional<Member> findByName(String name);
    List<Member> findAll();
}

member method

package hello.hellospring.repository;

import hello.hellospring.domain.Member;

import java.util.*;

public class MemoryMemberRepository implements MemberRepository{

    private static Map<Long, Member> store = new HashMap<>();
    private static long sequence = 0L;

    @Override
    public Member save(Member member) {
        member.setId(++sequence);
        store.put(member.getId(), member);
        return member;
    }

    @Override
    public Optional<Member> findById(Long id) {
        return Optional.ofNullable(store.get(id));
    }

    @Override
    public Optional<Member> findByName(String name) {
        return store.values().stream()
                .filter(member -> member.getName().equals(name))
                .findAny();
    }

    @Override
    public List<Member> findAll() {
        return new ArrayList<>(store.values());
    }

    public void clearStore() {
        store.clear();
    }
}

Implementing member repository test case

  • It is difficult to run many or repetitive tests in main method. Therefore, test case must be written. In java, JUnit, a framework, solves this problem.

How to implementate test cases for member repository

  • Create MemoryMemberRepositoryTest.java in this path
src/test/java/hello.hellospring/repository/MemoryMemberRepositoryTest.java
  • Type this into MemoryMemberRepositorytest.java
package hello.hellosrping.repository;

import hello.hellospring.domain.Member;
import org.junit.jupiter.api.AfterEach;
import org.junit.jupiter.api.Test;

import java.util.List;
import java.util.Optional;

import static org.assertj.core.api.Assertions.*;


class MemoryMemberRepositoryTest {

    MemoryMemberRepository repository = new MemoryMemberRepository();

    @AfterEach
    public void afterEach() {
        repository.clearStore();
    }

    @Test
    public void save() {
        Member member = new Member();
        member.setName("spring");

        repository.save(member);

        Member result = repository.findById(member.getId()).get();
        assertThat(member).isEqualTo(result);
    }

    @Test
    public void findByName() {
        Member member1 = new Member();
        member1.setName("spring1");
        repository.save(member1);

        Member member2 = new Member();
        member2.setName("spring1");
        repository.save(member2);

        Member result = repository.findByName("spring1").get();
        assertThat(result).isEqualTo(member1);
    }

    @Test
    public void findAll() {
        Member member1 = new Member();
        member1.setName("spring1");
        repository.save(member1);

        Member member2 = new Member();
        member2.setName("spring1");
        repository.save(member2);

        List<Member> result = repository.findAll();

        assertThat(result.size()).isEqualTo(2);
    }
}

Tip

  • TDD(Test-driven Development): Implement test case first before actual implementation of function

Developing member service

  • Create MemberService.java in this path
src/main/java/hello.hellospring/service/MemberService.java
  • Type this into MemberService.java
package hello.hellospring.service;

import hello.hellospring.domain.Member;
import hello.hellospring.repository.MemberRepository;
import hello.hellospring.repository.MemoryMemberRepository;

import java.util.List;
import java.util.Optional;

public class MemberService {

    private final MemberRepository memberRepository = new MemoryMemberRepository();

    public Long join(Member member) {
        validateDuplicateMember(member); // Verify duplicate member

        memberRepository.save(member);
        return member.getId();
    }

    private void validateDuplicateMember(Member member) {
        memberRepository.findByName(member.getName())
            .ifPresent(m -> {
                throw new IllegalStateException("Existing Member.");
            });
    }

    public List<Member> findMembers() {
        return memberRepository.findAll();
    }

    public Optional<Member> findOne(Long memberId) {
        return memberRepository.findById(memberId);
    }
}

Testing Member Service

  • Create MemberServiceTest.java in this path
src/test/java/hello.hellospring/service/MemberServiceTest.java
  • Type this into MemberServiceTest.java
package hello.hellospring.service;

import hello.hellospring.domain.Member;
import hello.hellospring.repository.MemoryMemberRepository;
import org.junit.jupiter.api.AfterEach;
import org.junit.jupiter.api.Assertions;
import org.junit.jupiter.api.BeforeEach;
import org.junit.jupiter.api.Test;

import static org.assertj.core.api.AssertionsForClassTypes.assertThat;
import static org.junit.jupiter.api.Assertions.*;

class MemberServiceTest {

    MemberService memberService;
    MemoryMemberRepository memberRepository;

    @BeforeEach
    public void beforeEach() {
        memberRepository = new MemoryMemberRepository();
        memberService = new MemberService(memberRepository);
    }

    @AfterEach
    public void afterEach() {
        memberRepository.clearStore();
    }


    @Test
    void join() {
        // given
        Member member = new Member();
        member.setName("spring");

        // when
        Long saveId = memberService.join(member);

        // then
        Member findMember = memberService.findOne(saveId).get();
        assertThat(member.getName()).isEqualTo(findMember.getName());
    }

    @Test
    public void duplicateMemberException() {
        //given
        Member member1 = new Member();
        member1.setName("spring");

        Member member2 = new Member();
        member2.setName("spring");

        //when
        memberService.join(member1);
        IllegalStateException e = assertThrows(IllegalStateException.class, () -> memberService.join(member2));
        assertThat(e.getMessage()).isEqualTo("Existing Member.");
        //then
    }

    @Test
    void findMembers() {
    }

    @Test
    void findOne() {
    }
}

Reference

  • https://www.inflearn.com/roadmaps/373

entry.title: Spring[2] - Web Development Basics
entry.content:
Spring [2] - Web Development Basics

There are 3 different kinds

  • Static Contents
  • MVC and Template Engine
  • API

Static content

  • Spring Boot static content function

How to create static content

  • Create hello-static.html in this path
resources/static/hello-static.html
  • Type this into hello-static.html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <title>static content</title>
    <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />
</head>
<body>
This is static content
</body>
</html>
  • Execute by typing
http://localhost:8080/hello-static.html

MVC and template engine

  • MVC: Model, View, Controller

  • Controller

@Controller
public class HelloController{
    @GetMapping("hello-mvc")
    public String helloMvc(@RequestParam("name") String name, Model model) {
        model.addAttribute("name", name);
        return "hello-template";
    }
}
  • View
resoucres/template/hello-template.html

<html xmlns:th="http://www.thymeleaf.org">
<body>
<p th:text="'hello ' + ${name}">hello! empty</p>
</body>
</html>
  • Execute by typing
http://localhost:8080/hello-mvc?name=spring

API

  • @ResponseBody character return
@Controller
public class HelloController {
    @GetMapping("hello-string")
    @ResponseBody
    public String helloString(@RequestParam("name") String name) {
        return "hello " + name;
    }
}
  • If @ResponseBody is used, viewResolver is not used

  • Instead HTTP BODY’s content is returned(Not HTML BODY TAG)

  • Execute by typing
http://localhost:8080/hello-string?name=spring
  • @ResponseBody object return
@Controller
public class HelloController {
    @GetMapping("hello-api")
    @ResponseBody
    public Hello helloApi(@RequestParam("name") String name) {
        Hello hello = new Hello();
        hello.setName(name);
        return hello;
    }

    static class Hello {
        private String name;

        public String getName() {
            return name;
        }

        public void setName(String name) {
            this.name = name;
        }
    }
}

  • Uses @ResponseBody and return object in JSON format

  • Execute by typing

http://localhost:8080/hello-api?name=spring
  • Principle of @ResponseBody
    • HTTP BODY’s character is directly returned
    • Instead of viewResolver, HttpMessageConverter is in action
    • Basic character process: StringHttpMessageConverter
    • Basic object process: MappingJackson2HttpMessageConverter
    • byte process and others use HttpMessageConverter

Reference

  • https://www.inflearn.com/roadmaps/373

entry.title: Spring[1] - Project Enviornment Setting
entry.content:
Spring [1] - Project Environment Setting

Preparation

  • Java
  • IDE: IntelliJ or Eclipse

Spring Boot Starter

  • https://start.spring.io

Tip

  • In actual field work, use log not print.
  • Gradle downloads all related dependencies together.

Spring Boot Libraires

  • spring-boot-starter-web
    • spring-boot-starter-tomcat: tomcat(webserver)
    • spring-webmvc: spring web MVC
  • spring-boot-starter-thymeleaf: thymeleaf template engine(view)
  • spring-boot-starter(common): spring boot + spring core + logging
    • spring-boot
      • spring-core
    • spring-boot-starter-logging -logback, slf4j

How to create welcome page

  • Create index.html in this path
resources/static/index.html
  • Type this into index.html
<!DOCTYPE HTML>
<html>
<head>
    <title>Hello</title>
    <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" />
</head>
<body>
Hello
<a href="/hello">hello</a>
</body>
</html>

How to build and execute

In console, type

  1. ./gradlew build
  2. cd build/libs
  3. java -jar hello-spring-0.0.1-SNAPSHOT.jar
  4. confirm execution

Reference

  • https://www.inflearn.com/roadmaps/373

entry.title: SQL - Overview
entry.content:
SQL - Overview

  • Many developers say that SQL is their go-to database when starting a new project, even though SQL is more than 40 years old
  • Billions of dollars were invested to create a new form of database(mongoDB, Cloud Firestore, etc.), but people still love SQL
  • MySQL is an open source database:
    • content management system like wordpress
    • ecommerce platforms like shopify
    • social media giants like twitter
  • CRUD
    • Create
    • Read
    • Update
    • Delete
  • Model and join relational data

History of SQL

  • Ted Codd, author of a legendary paper, published “A Relational Model of Data for Large Shared Data Banks” 50 years ago.
  • Before Tedd Codd published his paper, databases were not relational, they were network-based or hierarchical
  • In the paper, Tedd Codd outlines how a relational model can reduce duplication and redundancy, which change the way people approach databases
  • Few years after Ted Codd’s publication, Donald Chamberlin and Raymond Boyce used this paper as the bases for developing SQL(Structured Query Language)
  • Today SQL is in variety of format:
    • SQL Server
    • SQLite
    • MySQL
    • PostgreSQL

ORM(Object-Relational Mapping)

  • Developers do not write raw SQL code, they use libraries that perform ORM(Object-Relational Mapping), which is a tool that allow developers to work with relational databases using the object-oriented progamming language of your choice
    • Java - Hibernate
    • Javascript - Sequelize
    • Python - Alchemy
    • Ruby - Active record
  • Pros
    • Implementation in object oriented code: Don’t have to write SQL code
    • re-usability, maintance: ORM is object oriented, allowing its easy re-usability
  • Cons
    • Complexity: the more complex the project is, the difficulty of the blueprint increases
    • object-relation discord: discord between object and relation could occur

What is a RDBMS(Relational Database Management System)

  • Comprised of 2 main things
    • database: collection of table that consists of rows and columns like an excel spreadsheet
    • language: used to manipulate and read data in the database, which is a variation of structured query language

SQL Diagrams

  • Visualize and model data relationships:
    • tables = boxes
    • relationships = lines
      • one-to-one relationship
      • one-to-many relationship
      • many-to-many relationship

Relationship Example

  • A website consists of cryptocurrency trade will be used as a example case
  • One-to-one relationship
    • A user can only have one wallet
      • user - - wallet
  • One-to-many relationship
    • A user can have hold of many NFTs
      • user - = NFTs
  • Many-to-many relationship
    • A group of user can have hold of different cryto coin
      • user = = coin

Schemas, Datatypes, and Constraints

Schema

  • Database schema: blueprint that defines the different rules or constraints within the database
  • In the table, dictionary format of key and value exist
    • key = column
    • value = data

Datatype

  • Examples of datatypes
    • int: integer number
    • float: floating point number
    • varchar: small string
    • text: long strings
  • Choosing the correct datatype is important as it allows size and performance of the database to be optimized

Constraints

  • Examples of constraints:
    • unique: each value in the column is unique
    • not null: each value in the column is not null
    • primary key: each value cannot be null and it must be unique
  • primary key is especially important when building relationship database as a unique key can be saved in another table

Normalized Data Structure

  • Avoid data duplication as much as possible
  • Every entity must be organized into its smallest normal form which is a concept that Ted Cod suggested in his paper
  • Think of normalize data as breaking down a part into all of its inidividual parts

Basic SQL Syntax

  • A statement is code that does something
  • SQL keywords are not case sensitive, meaning you can write it in lowercase or uppercase, but sql keywords are written mostly in uppercase

DDL(Data Definition Language)

  • Defines the database schema
  • List of DDL
    • CREATE: create database or its object
    • DROP: delete objects from database
    • ALTER: alter the structure of the database
    • TRUNCATE: remove all records from a table
    • COMMENT: add comments to the data dictionary
    • RENAME: rename an object existing in the database
CREATE TABLE Users(
    id INT PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT,
    email VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL UNIQUE,
    bio TEXT,
    country VARCHAR(2)
);

DQL(Data Query Language)

  • Performs queries on the data within schema objects
  • List of DQL
    • SELECT: retrieve data from the database
SELECT email, id FROM Users
LIMIT 2;

DML(Data Manipulation Language)

  • Manipulation of data present in the database
  • List of DML
    • INSERT: insert data into a table
    • UPDATE: update existing data within a table
    • DELETE: delete records from a database table
    • LOCK: table control concurrency
    • CALL: call a PL/SQL or JAVA subprogram
    • EXPLAIN PLAN: describes the access path to data
INSERT INTO Users(email, bio, country)
VALUES(
    'hello@world.com',
    'i want to learn sql',
    'US'
);

DCL(Data Control Language)

  • Mainly deals with the rights, permission, and other controls
  • List of DCL
    • GRANT: gives user access privileges to the database
    • REVOKE: withdraws the user’s access privileges given by using the GRANT command

TCL(Transaction Control Language)

  • Deals with the transaction within the database
  • List of TCL
    • COMMIT: commits a transaction
    • ROLLBACK: rollbacks a transaction in case of any error occurs
    • SAVEPOINT: sets a savepoint within a transaction
    • SET TRANSACTION: specify characteristics for the transaction

Reference

  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Cz3WcZLRaWc
  • hhttps://www.geeksforgeeks.org/sql-ddl-dql-dml-dcl-tcl-commands/
entry.summary: SQL - Overview Many developers say that SQL is their go-to database when starting a new project, even though SQL is more than 40 years old Billions of dollars were invested to create a new form of database(mongoDB, Cloud Firestore, etc.), but people still love SQL MySQL is an open source database: content management system like wordpress ecommerce platforms like shopify social media giants like twitter CRUD Create Read Update Delete Model and join relational data

entry.title: Speech[1] - Overview
entry.content:
Speech[1] - Overview

Application

  • Audio Classification
  • Speech Recognition
  • Speaker Verification
  • Audio Denoising
  • Audio Upsampling
  • Music Information Retrieval
    • Music Instrument Classification
    • Mood Classification
  • …

Two stages for Speech Processing

  • Preparing Audio Data
  • Development & Evaluation of Model

Technology commonly used

  • Python
  • Tensorflow / PyTorch
  • Librosa
  • …

Reference

  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iCwMQJnKk2c&list=PL-wATfeyAMNqIee7cH3q1bh4QJFAaeNv0

entry.title: Speech[2] - Mel spectrogram Explanation
entry.content:
Speech[2] - Mel spectrogram Explanation

Humans perceive frequency logarithmically

How to calculate Mel frequency using Frequency

How to calculate Frequency using Mel frequency

How to extract Mel spectrogram

  1. Extract STFT
  2. Convert amplitude to DBs
  3. Convert frequencies to Mel scale

How to convert frequencies to Mel scale

  1. Choose number of mel bands
    • Number of mel bands(e.g. 40, 60, 90, 128) depends on the problem
  2. Construct mel filter banks
  3. Apply mel filter banks to spectrogram
